author: HCAndersen
text: FROM my father I received the best inheritance, namely a "good temper."

author: HCAndersen
text: "And who was my father?"

author: HCAndersen
text: That has nothing to do with the good temper; but I will say he was lively, good-looking round, and fat; he was both in appearance and character a complete contradiction to his profession.

author: HCAndersen
text: "And pray what was his profession and his standing in respectable society?"

author: HCAndersen
text: Well, perhaps, if in the beginning of a book these were written and printed, many, when they read it, would lay the book down and say, "It seems to me a very miserable title, I don't like things of this sort."

author: HCAndersen
text: And yet my father was not a skin-dresser nor an executioner; on the contrary, his employment placed him at the head of the grandest people of the town, and it was his place by right.

author: HCAndersen
text: He had to precede the bishop, and even the princes of the blood; he always went first,- he was a hearse driver!

author: HCAndersen
text: There, now, the truth is out.

author: HCAndersen
text: And I will own, that when people saw my father perched up in front of the omnibus of death, dressed in his long, wide, black cloak, and his black-edged, three-cornered hat on his head, and then glanced at his round, jocund face, round as the sun, they could not think much of sorrow or the grave.

author: HCAndersen
text: That face said, "It is nothing, it will all end better than people think."

author: HCAndersen
text: So I have inherited from him, not only my good temper, but a habit of going often to the churchyard, which is good, when done in a proper humor; and then also I take in the Intelligencer, just as he used to do.

author: HCAndersen
text: I am not very young, I have neither wife nor children, nor a library, but, as I said, I read the Intelligencer, which is enough for me; it is to me a delightful paper, and so it was to my father.

author: HCAndersen
text: It is of great use, for it contains all that a man requires to know; the names of the preachers at the church, and the new books which are published; where houses, servants, clothes, and provisions may be obtained.

author: HCAndersen
text: And then what a number of subscriptions to charities, and what innocent verses!

author: HCAndersen
text: Persons seeking interviews and engagements, all so plainly and naturally stated.

author: HCAndersen
text: Certainly, a man who takes in the Intelligencer may live merrily and be buried contentedly, and by the end of his life will have such a capital stock of paper that he can lie on a soft bed of it, unless he prefers wood shavings for his resting-place.

author: HCAndersen
text: The newspaper and the churchyard were always exciting objects to me.

author: HCAndersen
text: My walks to the latter were like bathing-places to my good humor.

author: HCAndersen
text: Every one can read the newspaper for himself, but come with me to the churchyard while the sun shines and the trees are green, and let us wander among the graves.

author: HCAndersen
text: Each of them is like a closed book, with the back uppermost, on which we can read the title of what the book contains, but nothing more.

author: HCAndersen
text: I had a great deal of information from my father, and I have noticed a great deal myself.

author: HCAndersen
text: I keep it in my diary, in which I write for my own use and pleasure a history of all who lie here, and a few more beside.

author: HCAndersen
text: Now we are in the churchyard.

author: HCAndersen
text: Here, behind the white iron railings, once a rose-tree grew; it is gone now, but a little bit of evergreen, from a neighboring grave, stretches out its green tendrils, and makes some appearance; there rests a very unhappy man, and yet while he lived he might be said to occupy a very good position.

author: HCAndersen
text: He had enough to live upon, and something to spare; but owing to his refined tastes the least thing in the world annoyed him.

author: HCAndersen
text: If he went to a theatre of an evening, instead of enjoying himself he would be quite annoyed if the machinist had put too strong a light into one side of the moon, or if the representations of the sky hung over the scenes when they ought to have hung behind them; or if a palm-tree was introduced into a scene representing the Zoological Gardens of Berlin, or a cactus in a view of Tyrol, or a beech-tree in the north of Norway.

author: HCAndersen
text: As if these things were of any consequence!

author: HCAndersen
text: Why did he not leave them alone?

author: HCAndersen
text: Who would trouble themselves about such trifles? especially at a comedy, where every one is expected to be amused.

author: HCAndersen
text: Then sometimes the public applauded too much, or too little, to please him.

author: HCAndersen
text: "They are like wet wood," he would say, looking round to see what sort of people were present, "this evening; nothing fires them."

author: HCAndersen
text: Then he would vex and fret himself because they did not laugh at the right time, or because they laughed in the wrong places; and so he fretted and worried himself till at last the unhappy man fretted himself into the grave.

author: HCAndersen
text: Here rests a happy man, that is to say, a man of high birth and position, which was very lucky for him, otherwise he would have been scarcely worth notice.

author: HCAndersen
text: It is beautiful to observe how wisely nature orders these things.

author: HCAndersen
text: He walked about in a coat embroidered all over, and in the drawing-rooms of society looked just like one of those rich pearl-embroidered bell-pulls, which are only made for show; and behind them always hangs a good thick cord for use.

author: HCAndersen
text: This man also had a stout, useful substitute behind him, who did duty for him, and performed all his dirty work.

author: HCAndersen
text: And there are still, even now, these serviceable cords behind other embroidered bell-ropes.

author: HCAndersen
text: It is all so wisely arranged, that a man may well be in a good humor.

author: HCAndersen
text: Here rests,- ah, it makes one feel mournful to think of him!- but here rests a man who, during sixty-seven years, was never remembered to have said a good thing; he lived only in the hope of having a good idea.

author: HCAndersen
text: At last he felt convinced, in his own mind, that he really had one, and was so delighted that he positively died of joy at the thought of having at last caught an idea.

author: HCAndersen
text: Nobody got anything by it; indeed, no one even heard what the good thing was.

author: HCAndersen
text: Now I can imagine that this same idea may prevent him from resting quietly in his grave; for suppose that to produce a good effect, it is necessary to bring out his new idea at breakfast, and that he can only make his appearance on earth at midnight, as ghosts are believed generally to do; why then this good idea would not suit the hour, and the man would have to carry it down again with him into the grave- that must be a troubled grave.

author: HCAndersen
text: The woman who lies here was so remarkably stingy, that during her life she would get up in the night and mew, that her neighbors might think she kept a cat.

author: HCAndersen
text: What a miser she was!

author: HCAndersen
text: Here rests a young lady, of a good family, who would always make her voice heard in society, and when she sang "Mi manca la voce,"* it was the only true thing she ever said in her life.

author: HCAndersen
text: * "I want a voice," or, "I have no voice."

author: HCAndersen
text: Here lies a maiden of another description.

author: HCAndersen
text: She was engaged to be married,- but, her story is one of every-day life; we will leave her to rest in the grave.

author: HCAndersen
text: Here rests a widow, who, with music in her tongue, carried gall in her heart.

author: HCAndersen
text: She used to go round among the families near, and search out their faults, upon which she preyed with all the envy and malice of her nature.

author: HCAndersen
text: This is a family grave.

author: HCAndersen
text: The members of this family held so firmly together in their opinions, that they would believe in no other.

author: HCAndersen
text: If the newspapers, or even the whole world, said of a certain subject, "It is so-and-so;" and a little schoolboy declared he had learned quite differently, they would take his assertion as the only true one, because he belonged to the family.

author: HCAndersen
text: And it is well known that if the yard-cock belonging to this family happened to crow at midnight, they would declare it was morning, although the watchman and all the clocks in the town were proclaiming the hour of twelve at night.

author: HCAndersen
text: The great poet Goethe concludes his Faust with the words, "may be continued;" so might our wanderings in the churchyard be continued.

author: HCAndersen
text: I come here often, and if any of my friends, or those who are not my friends, are too much for me, I go out and choose a plot of ground in which to bury him or her.

author: HCAndersen
text: Then I bury them, as it were; there they lie, dead and powerless, till they come back new and better characters.

author: HCAndersen
text: Their lives and their deeds, looked at after my own fashion, I write down in my diary, as every one ought to do.

author: HCAndersen
text: Then, if any of our friends act absurdly, no one need to be vexed about it.

author: HCAndersen
text: Let them bury the offenders out of sight, and keep their good temper.

author: HCAndersen
text: They can also read the Intelligencer, which is a paper written by the people, with their hands guided.

author: HCAndersen
text: When the time comes for the history of my life, to be bound by the grave, then they will write upon it as my epitaph-

author: HCAndersen
text: "The man with a cheerful temper."

author: HCAndersen
text: And this is my story.
